isis.stitle: HEAT VENTILATION AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC), Orifice Tube System, Pre-March 2007 - 3200, 4100, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 7600, 7700, 8500, 8600 - TROUBLESHOOTING QUICK TIPS - COMMON CONDITIONS THAT CAUSE POOR OR NO A/C OPERATION

svcproc.title: COMMON CONDITIONS THAT CAUSE POOR OR NO A/C OPERATION
svcproc.para: This section lists some of the more common conditions encountered with malfunctioning HVAC systems.

item.para: If the AC Request line (wire A77) is open from the HVAC control head to the ESC, the A/C system will not operate and a DTC will not be set by the ESC. Check for this condition using the EZ-Tech (see SECTION 20.3 or SECTION 9).

If a thermistor value is displayed as 0 (zero) in the diagnostic software, check the thermistor wiring for an open circuit. (This could also be caused by corrosion on the thermistor connector contacts.) Note the thermistor DTC, if one is set; then, refer to SECTION 15
to troubleshoot the thermistor circuits.

para.emph: NOTE: If the electrical connection to either thermistor is suspected of being intermittent, perform the THERMISTOR CONNECTOR REPAIR procedures .

item.para:
If the thermistor value is displayed as NA in the diagnostic software, check the thermistor wiring for a short to ground. Note the thermistor DTC, if one is set; then, refer to SECTION 15
to troubleshoot the thermistor circuits.

The high head pressure DTC (613-14A-1-10) will activate when the pressure transducer measures 400 psi if vehicle speed is over 20 mph. Refer to SECTION 8.1
for a more complete understanding of the pressure transducer circuit. Refer to TABLE 12
to troubleshoot a high head pressure condition.

On some vehicles it was possible for DTC 613-14A-1-6 (Marginal Charge) to be set and latched when there was no malfunction. With the current ESC software version, this is now an invalid code. If this code is being displayed, refer to DTC 613-14-1-6 in TABLE 3
for instructions on how to proceed.
To clear a latched, active HVAC code (such as 613-14A-1-6):
Turn the HVAC Fan control to OFF.
Using the Cruise Control switches place the ESC into diagnostic mode to display the DTC's. Refer to DIAGNOSTIC TROUBLE CODES .
Cycle the ignition switch off and then back on.
Place the ESC into the diagnostic mode again. The HVAC code should now be inactive.

Excessive oil in the system will cause the system to not operate properly, and too little oil can damage the compressor. When performing any service that requires charging the system, carefully follow the procedures in SECTION 7.10
to insure that the correct quantity of oil is maintained in the system.
